newsitem.title: USA: Feds order Friendly's to redesign restaurants.
newsitem.headline: Feds order Friendly's to redesign restaurants.

text.p: Friendly's restaurants, one of the largest family-style chains in the nation, reached agreement on Monday with the Department of Justice to make its 704 restaurants more accessible to disabled people.
As part of the agreement, which was reached under the Americans with Disabilities Act, Friendly's agreed to pay a $50,000 fine, said Attorney General Janet Reno.

"The agreement will serve as a model to others in the restaurant industry," she told a press conference here. "For diners with disabilities, ADA compliance is the real welcome sign on the door of every restaurant," added Reno, who was also in town to accept an honorary doctor of laws degree from Boston College.

Barriers such as curbs, steps and narrow doorways restricted wheelchair access to 93 of the 704 Friendly's located in 15 states, where diners routinely are offered sundaes with their meals, U.S. Attorney Donald Stern told the press conference.

Friendly's has agreed to redesign the restaurants over a six-year period and will modify counter heights and make entrances, telephones, mirrors, paper towel dispensers and doorknobs all accessible to people with handicaps.
A Friendly's spokeswoman said the company was pleased with the agreement.
